Environmental autocorrelation also affects population variability and can accentuate the effects of high mortality in early life stages. We use simulations of Model-2 to evaluate the combined effect of increasing mortality and environmental autocorrelation. For these simulations we chose different values of s 0 and different values of the correlation coefficient ρ of the environmental variability. In each simulation the other survival coefficients s
k were those for the leatherback sea turtle. The fecundities f
k for the leatherback were also used, without environmental variability. In the presence of environmental variability all survival coefficients s
k were multiplied by the random variable exp( ε
t ) as in Eq ( 6). Here σ 2, the variance in Eq ( 7), is chosen such that the standard deviation of ε
t is exactly 0.1 over the duration of the run.
